author: Keith Perry
title: Theresa May orders GPs to open 7 days-a-week or lose funding in bid to tackle A&E crisis
text:
Theresa May has taken the extraordinary step of intervening to order GPs to offer more appointments (Photo: PA) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Theresa May has ordered GPs to offer appointments 8am to 8pm seven days a week or lose funding. 
In an extraordinary personal intervention, the PM has demanded easier access to surgeries to help tackle overcrowding in NHS hospitals . 
The move comes as patients unable to see a GP are turning up at hospital casualty units. 
Nearly half of England’s hospitals were struggling so badly last week that they declared ‘operational pressure alerts. 
Six issued the highest level warning where patients’ safety was judged at risk. Read More GPs have been ordered to open 7 days-a-week (Photo: Getty Images) May has warned GPs do not offer enough out-of-hours care (file photo) (Photo: Getty) 
Thousands of GP surgeries close on weekday afternoons while others take a three hour lunch break. 
The Prime Minister will demand that GP surgeries offer extended hours open from 8am to 8pm seven days a week unless they can prove that there is not a demand in their area. 
A major package of government funding will be “contingent” on GPs being able to demonstrate that they are offering appointments “when patients wanted them”, ministers will say. The NHS is in crisis with a shortage of beds (Photo: Getty) A&E departments are under increasing pressure (Photo: Getty) 
They will be required to give Whitehall officials detailed information on the number and type of appointments they offer. 
This must cover evening and weekend appointments as well as evidence that these slots are being advertised. 
Those that fail to meet the criteria will lose cash allocated to the NHS to expand surgery hours. Read More The Red Cross claimed the NHS is in a 'humanitarian crisis' (Photo: Daily Mirror) Waiting times in A&E are higher than ever (Photo: PA) 
A Downing Street source said: “Most GPs do a fantastic job and have their patients’ interest firmly at heart. However it is increasingly clear that a large number of surgeries are not providing proper out of hours care - and that patients are suffering as a result because they are then forced to go to A&E . 
“It is also bad for hospitals which then face additional pressure on their services. That’s why ministers are calling on GPs to deliver on their commitments - while introducing reforms to deliver in the interests of patients.” 
Ministers say they have been shown evidence that some GP surgeries are failing to tell patients about extended hours appointments or ensure that they are at times that patients want. Number 10 says this means that some patients are left with little option but to go to A&E. Like us on Facebook
